fields.label_text:
2. GIRDLE
Worn at festivals by peasants of Piana dei Greci, Palermo, Sicily.
SICILIAN (Palermo mark): second half of 18th century.
Marks, (?) SCC and AM (buckle); PC 710 (girdle).
Given by Mrs. Richards
M.65-1949

fields.descriptive_line: Silver, Sicily (Piana degli Albanesi), the belt stamped with Palermo assay officer's mark for 1710, the clasp c. 1750.
fields.physical_description: Belt made of 13 cast square silver sections of open-work with a rayed sun in the centre of each section, joined with two cast silver links in the shape of flowers. The clasp of silver with a cast image of St George slaying the dragon beneath a canopy, cherubs either side of the saint.
fields.dimensions:
Height: 13 cm clasp only, Width: 14 cm clasp only, Depth: 2.5 cm clasp; approximate depth, Weight: 273.9 g clasp only, Length: 62.7 cm belt only; includes clasps at the end, Width: 5.5 cm belt, Depth: 1 cm belt; approximate depth, Weight: 582.7 g belt
[girdle (belt)] Height: 5 cm, Width: 63.6 cm includes clasps at the end of the links., Depth: 0.8 cm, Weight: 582.7 g
[clasp for a girdle] Height: 12.9 cm, Width: 13.6 cm, Depth: 2.4 cm, Weight: 273.9 g
fields.label:
2. GIRDLE
Worn at festivals by peasants of Piana dei Greci, Palermo, Sicily.
SICILIAN (Palermo mark): second half of 18th century.
Marks, (?) SCC and AM (buckle); PC 710 (girdle).
Given by Mrs. Richards
M.65-1949 [1970-1980]
fields.marks:
Eagle with lowered wings over letters R.V.P.  Mark for silver, Palermo, before around 1710.
 'P.C.710' in rectangular frame.  Mark of assay master Placido Caruso, of Palermo, 1710.
 'PC' and star in rectangular frame.  Mark of unidentified maker
 Eagle with raised wings over letters R.V.P.  Mark for silver, Palermo, after around 1710.
 'A.M.' in rectangular frame.  Mark of unidentified maker.
 Illegible mark, possibly ending in '2', in rectangular frame.  Assay master's mark
 Partial mark of an eagle with raised wings.  Mark for silver, Palermo, after around 1710.
[girdle (belt)] The initials PC and the number 710 in a rectangular punch, separated by a pellet: the mark of the unidentified Palermo assay master for the year 1710.
The eagle with wings folded downwards above the letters R V P separated by pellets, in an irregular-shaped punch: the mark of the Palermo assay office.
The initials PC followed by a star, in a rectangular-shaped punch: mark of the goldsmith, perhaps Placido Caruso (see Accascina: 1976, p. 55).
[clasp for a girdle] Zig-zag assay mark on the back of the clasp.
[clasp for a girdle] On front of buckle, beneath front hooves of horse, worn mark of Palermo assay office for 1710: an eagle with wings folded downwards above the letters R V P separated by pellets, in an irregular-shaped punch.
The letters R V P are an abbreviation for Regia Vrbs Panormi (ie. Royal Town of Palermo).
[clasp for a girdle] 'A.M.' - maker's mark, punched on the flat base of the front of the clasp, at the right end of the crown.
fields.public_access_description:
This belt and clasp are characteristic of a type of costume ornament worn by the women of the Albanian community of Piana degli Albanesi, Sicily. The belt is known as a 'brezi', from the Albanian word 'brez', meaning 'race' or 'progeny', and the term refers to the function of the belt as a symbol of motherhood. A 'brezi' is an important element in the ritual leading up to marriage and subsequent motherhood, as the bride-to-be wears it as she displays her dowry. The clasp ('borchia') which fastens the belt is decorated with the image of the local patron saint, in this case St George.
The belt and clasp are traditionally the most important pieces of jewellery worn by the women of this community.
fields.bibliography:
Accascina, Maria. <u>I Marchi delle Argenterie e Oreficerie Siciliane</u>. Busto Arsizio: Bramante Editrice, 1976
<u>Piana degli Albanesi / Hora e Arbëreshëvet</u>. Quaderni di Biblos, 1/10. Palermo: Comune di Piana degli Albanesi and Biblioteca comunale Giuseppe Schiro di Piana degli Albanesi, 2000. Guidebook to the area and its customs.
The copy in the National Art Library is the 1991 edition.
For 'brezi', see p 98 (2000 edn).
Francesco Polizzi, 'Splendori di Sicilia al Victoria and Albert Museum' (doctoral thesis), Palermo, 2011, p.188.
S.J.A. Churchill, 'Peasant Jewellery' in 'Peasant Art in Italy', a special edition of 'The Studio', Autumn 1913, fig. 300.
Perry, Jane. <u>Traditional Jewellery in Nineteenth-Century Europe</u>. London: V&A Publishing, 2013. ISBN 9781851777297
See colour plate 106 (p. 82).
Concetta di Natale, Maria. <u>Ore e argenti di Sicilia dal Quattrocento al Settecento.</u> Catalogue of an exhibition held at the Museo Regionale Pepoli, Trapani, July 1-Oct. 30, 1989. Milan: Electa, 1989. ISBN 8843528491
Another example of a silver, Sicilian belt from 1711, decorated with scenes from the life of Jesus and Mary.
fields.credit: Given by Mrs E. M. Richards
fields.history_note: This belt was given to the V&A in 1949 by Mrs Euphrosyne M. Richards, née Whitaker.  She presumably inherited it from her mother, the famous Sicilian collector Euphrosyne (Effie) Whitaker, née Manuel. It was recorded as owned by her when illustrated by the British Consul-General Sidney J.A. Churchill in a special issue of 'The Studio' devoted to Peasant Art in Italy in 1913.
